key_findings: NO SUBSCRIPTION accounts have HIGHEST bug reporting rate: 50.00%
Medium MRR accounts have similar bug rate to high MRR: 47.37% vs 44.44%
Low MRR accounts have LOWEST bug reporting rate: 16.67%
Bug reporting rate is U-SHAPED: high at extremes (no subscription & high MRR), low in middle (low MRR)
Enterprise accounts WITHOUT subscriptions report bugs at 80% rate - highest of all segments
Within High MRR: Pro plans report MORE bugs (66.67%) than Enterprise (25.00%)
Within Medium MRR: Free plans report MORE bugs (62.50%) than paid plans
Low MRR segment shows MINIMAL bug reporting across all plans

surprising_patterns: Accounts with NO subscription report MORE bugs than paying low-value customers
Free trial/evaluation users (no subscription, enterprise plan) are extremely likely to report bugs (80%)
Low-value customers report FEWER bugs - possibly less engaged or fewer features used

business_implications: NO SUBSCRIPTION accounts (likely trials/evaluation) are highly engaged and report many bugs
This suggests TRIAL USERS are actively testing the product and finding issues
Low MRR customers may be less engaged or using fewer features (less bug exposure)
High-value customers report bugs at moderate rates - engaged but perhaps more tolerant
Bug reports from NO SUBSCRIPTION accounts are CRITICAL - these are potential high-value customers evaluating
The 80% bug rate for Enterprise no-subscription suggests evaluation/trial phase needs attention
Low MRR segment's low bug rate (16.67%) suggests either: limited usage, high tolerance, or feature limitations
recommendations: PRIORITIZE bug fixes for trial/evaluation users (no subscription) - they're actively evaluating and finding issues
Focus on improving trial experience - 80% of enterprise trials report bugs
Investigate why low MRR customers report fewer bugs - are they less engaged?
Consider that bug reporting is a sign of ENGAGEMENT, not necessarily dissatisfaction
Use bug reports from trial users as early warning signals for onboarding friction
